From Washington to Kansas and beyond, it is time to reach across the aisle and move forward in finally fixing our broken immigration system.
In our roles as physician from Kansas and immigrant rights advocate, we saw the same thing: immigrants are a vital part of America's future.
We should give them a fair shot by creating a process that is easier to navigate, crosses over industries, and keeps families together.
The truth is that immigrant workers want to provide valuable labor - and we should truly value it - and we need that labor.
In @RepMarshall's Kansas, 56% of Fortune 500 companies were founded by immigrants or their kids, providing 11K jobs and billions in revenue.
We found plenty of common ground. In Washington state, 60 percent of Fortune 500 companies were founded by immigrants or their children.
For all of us, we recognize that so much of the rhetoric around immigration is neither true nor conducive to finding real solutions.
We met again, with about half Republicans and Democrats in the room. We all shared why addressing our immigration system is important to us.
After a visit to the Holocaust Museum a few months ago, we found ourselves in deep discussion on immigration.

I urge support for our Dignity for Detained Immigrants Act, H.R. 3923.
Here is what our bill does:pic.twitter.com/mtpviHxkuD
As net migration sits at zero, as Dreamers are under attack, as unprecedented numbers of refugees seek safety—we must act with compassion.
Congress cannot sit on the sidelines. We must make clear that locking people up without due process is unconstitutional and un-American.
Our bill is about two things: dignity and justice. It is unconscionable to detain vulnerable people for months or even years.
Daily, nearly 38,000 people are detained—pregnant women, kids, parents. This inhumanity comes at a cost of $2 billion a year to taxpayers.
Our detention system brings huge profits for large, private corporations. In 2015, these groups made $765 million off of detentions.
It’s time to dismantle Trump's deportation machine. My Dignity for Detained Immigrants Act with @RepAdamSmith is a crucial first step.pic.twitter.com/knKh1Nodz1

Daniel: I fell ill in detention, was taken to the hospital in chains. You are punished if you share what little food you get with others.
Daniel, who spent 5 months in this incarceration system, calls his experience "terrible" and calls on lawmakers to pass this bill.
I want to thank @RepAdamSmith and @RepRoybalAllard for their strong leadership in tackling the abuses in the immigrant incarceration system.pic.twitter.com/syLDuHb1BA
It's unconscionable to separate moms and dads, to detain pregnant women for no good reason. Our bill allows more families to stay together.
The incarceration system for immigrants operates in the shadows, at a huge profit for corporations. Our bill phases them out in 3 years.
Immigration is supposed to be a civil system, but this is effectively an incarceration system. More than 350,000 people were held last year.
We are thrilled to have 39 co-sponsors for this bill. This legislation is critical to dismantling Trump's mass deportation machine.

No great movement has ever been easy. The fight for our climate, our jobs and our rights will be tough. But when we join forces, we win.
Our movement is strong, but we'll build more strength by not only calling people out, but by calling them in to find common ground.
It's also why @RepMcEachin, @RepBarragan and I created the Environmental Justice Task Force. Climate policy should be justice-focused.
That's why I co-sponsored a bill to get the U.S. to 100 percent renewable energy by 2050. The #100by50 Act lays out a path for our future.
...we must also propose the vision of what we want the world to look like. We must be a proposition party that puts ideas into action.
And as we oppose the stripping of environmental regulations, the disregard for people of color and policies that are bad for workers…
We must fight the rules that allow big business to profit at the expense of our communities and our climate. We must oppose climate deniers.
So, we need to lengthen the decision-making table to ensure space for communities of color, environmental leaders AND organized labor.
Though it is more complex to build coalitions and find solutions that work for everyone, the most surefire way to lose is to go it alone.
From collective bargaining to a fair minimum wage to clean energy and jobs transition - we fight together so we all rise together.
We can't be fooled by false choices. It is not jobs OR environment; economy OR morality. We must defend all these things all the time.
The strongest movements are built when we join together—at the intersections of labor, environment, jobs and organizing, we find our power.

AAPI voices are critical in this fight. Now, we must pass the DREAM Act so that people like Amy can continue to access the American dream.
Amy’s story represents how deeply affected Asian American and Pacific Islanders are by immigration policy. There are 12,000 AAPI Dreamers.
DACA recognized that Dreamers are so tightly woven into the fabric of our country that deporting them would rip communities apart.
DACA gave people like Amy a chance to be fully human again and it allowed America the privilege of benefitting from her talents. #DefendDACA
Her story is compelling, but not unique. Nearly 800k have benefited from DACA since 2012. Now Trump is throwing Dreamers' lives into limbo.
Without a work permit, the livelihood of her family is at stake. If Amy was deported, her youngest sister could be sent to foster care.
Amy is also undocumented. She hasn't seen her parents since age 11. Without DACA, Amy fears never being able to complete her nursing degree.
Amy Kele is a nursing student at @UW and health care worker in my district. Amy provides for her 3 siblings and is an active church member.

A: Mattis didn't even know about the ban when it was handed down. I've been disgusted. Trump throwing red meat to a tiny part of his base.

A: I'm a longtime supporter of single payer. Co-sponsoring the Conyers #MedicareforAll bill. Also working to free up states to pursue it.
Q from Seattle: When do we get single payer healthcare? Why do Congress members get better healthcare than constituents?
A (2/2): We need to all work to preserve opportunity for all to lead decent lives - and make sure corporations are paying their fair share.
A (1/2): Deal struck with GOP yesterday preserves leverage over next 3 months for minority to act on healthcare and DREAM Act and more.
Q: We're all human beings - how do we organize together to make our views on what is going on loud and clear?
A: It's terrible and you've articulated the deep emotional trauma that people are going through. Deporting DREAMers is untenable.
Q from Seattle: My Hispanic family is worried. Children are in school, family members are working. What happens if they are sent away?
A: I led voter reg. drives as OneAmerica director. We must resist voter suppression, and we need candidates that reflect our communities.
Q from Diane in Lake Forest Park: How can we help minority communities vote in elections so their interests are protected?
A: Our immigration system is broken - it's not so simple. Worked for 15 yrs from the outside to fix it, and we're going to keep on pushing.
Q from Shoreline: Why can't DREAMers simply use the traditional or typical path to become citizens?
A: It was not unconstitutional, but now we are in a situation where Congress needs to act. Appreciate your support for the DREAM Act!
Q from Robert in Edmonds, who says he supports Trump as well as the 2017 DREAM Act: Was Obama's DACA directive unconstitutional?
A: Does GOP want to throw out DREAMers? Their base is actually against it, including much of the Trump base. We have momentum and leverage.
Second Q, coming from Vashon: There has been plenty of bipartisan support for DREAMers - what happened to that and how do we pass a bill?
A: Open to compromise. 2013 immigration bill had some bad aspects, but accomplished greater good. But hopeful about a clean DACA bill.

The amendment would have ensured we focus on fixing this broken system, as opposed to funding more deadly detention facilities.
Now we're seeing the highest number of deaths in ICE custody since 2011. For-profit detention centers aren't abiding by basic standards.
In FY 2017, ICE had capacity to detain an unprecedented 39,324 men, women, and children. The system is plagued with inhumane conditions.
The US operates the world's largest immigration detention system. My second amendment would have placed a moratorium on further expansion.pic.twitter.com/lGHF4fON5G
Instead of expanding Trump’s mass deportation force, we should be strengthening oversight and accountability over @DHSgov.
DHS OIG also received 402 reports of “coerced sexual contact,” 196 complaints of “sexual harassment,” and 380 of “physical or sexual abuse.”
Only  2.4%  of those sexual abuse complaints from detention facilities were ever investigated, according to CIVIC, a watchdog group.
From 2014-2016, the @DHSOIG received 1,016 reports of sexual abuse in detention - that's more than one complaint of sexual abuse each day.
My amendment would have eliminated $535 million in new funding for ICE and provided $30 million to DHS civil rights and oversight bodies.

My bill with @RepBrianHiggins says transparency and accountability matter. No CBO score, no vote on the floor. It's just common sense.
So, we introduced H.Res. 441 to demand every piece of legislation that comes to the House floor gets a @USCBO score BEFORE votes are cast.
Forcing votes on bills we don't have full detail on is reckless—but it's what @HouseGOP did with #Trumpcare. We can't let it happen again.
Without it, members of Congress can't know what a bill will do for their constituents. Knowing the CBO score is simply good governance.
For years, @USCBO has been a nonpartisan staple in crafting legislation. It tells us how much a bill will cost and who it will help or hurt.
It's simple—Congress needs to know the impact that bills will have before a vote. @RepBrianHiggins and I want a #ScoreBeforetheFloor.pic.twitter.com/W86tBWBcHV

The White House is a public office, but Trump's entire presidency can be seen as a promotion of his own private business interests.pic.twitter.com/AS2a8rS2ka
The American people have a right to know to what the web conflicts of interests are and to demand the president put their interests first.
The American people should also be deeply concerned about conflicts of interest with the operations at the president’s Mar-a-Lago resort.
Trump was in violation of that clause the moment he was inaugurated. This lease should be terminated, effective immediately.
Trump Tower in D.C. is one example. The government lease stipulates "any elected official" may not derive benefits from it.
It can be used by domestic and foreign governments to curry favor and produce personal benefits.
Trump's entire presidency can be seen as a promotion of his business interests and his personal empire.
There is no wall erected between Trump's businesses and his presidency and anyone who wants to buy influence can simply do so openly.
It is deeply disturbing that this president has refused to release his tax returns or create a blind trust for the proceeds of his assets.
Trump’s enormous web of businesses and conflicts of interest make clear the need to explicitly expand this restriction to the presidency.
If we're holding agencies accountable for their statements, then we need to hold the president to those same standards.
I just proposed an amendment to restrict Trump from making public statements to promote his own business interests. #EmolumentsClause
